questions.question: A 2-month-old baby was brought with complaints of fever and fast breathing for 5 days, andwas diagnosed with pneumonia. Further history revealed baby had recurrent infections.Blood culture revealed infection from Nocardia spp. Nitroblue tetrazolium test turned out tobe negative. Which of the following statement is false regarding this condition?

options.B: It is due to oxidase deficiency

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests chronic granulomatous disease. It is due to a macrophage-richchronic inflammatory reaction, not lymphocytic.Chronic granulomatous disease is a defect in bacterial killing and renders patients susceptible torecurrent bacterial infections. The name of this disease comes from the macrophage-rich chronicinflammatory reaction that tries to control the infection when the initial neutrophil defense isinadequate. This often leads to collections of activated macrophages that wall off the microbes,forming granulomas.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent swelling of the face and lips as shown with vomiting anddiarrhea when emotionally stressed. What is the most likely deficiency?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary angioneurotic edema. It is due tothe deficiency of C1 inhibitors.Hereditary angioneurotic edema is an autosomal dominant disorder, which is more common thancomplement deficiency states.Targets of C1 inhibitors are proteases, specifically Cır and Cis of the complement cascade, factorXII of the coagulation pathway, and the kallikrein system. Deficiency of C1 inhibitor leads tounregulated activation of kallikrein. This increases the production of vasoactive peptides such asbradykinin.It causes episodes of edema affecting the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the larynx and thegastrointestinal tract. This may result in life-threatening asphyxia or nausea, vomiting, anddiarrhea after minor trauma or emotional stress.

questions.question: A 4-month-old baby was brought with severe diaper rash. The parents gave a history ofrecurrent infections in the past 4 months which required frequent hospitalization. Onexamination white patches were present in oral mucosa which could be scraped easily. Thebiopsy of the thymus showed remnants of Hassall's corpuscles. Which of the followingstatements is false about this condition?

options.C: It is due to defect only in cell mediated immune response289
options.D: B cell count can be normal

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). The biopsyof the thymus showing remnants of Hassall's corpuscles indicates it is due to adenosinedeaminase (ADA) deficiency. SCID is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immuneresponses. Usually the defect lies in the T-cell compartment with secondary impairment inhumoral immunity.Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, andfailure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal Tcells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease(GVHD).Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range ofpathogens, including:• Candida albicans•Pneumocystis jiroveci• Pseudomonas• Cytomegalovirus• VaricellaThere are 2 types of SCID based on inheritance:1. X-linked SCID is the most common form and hence it is more common in boys than in girls.The genetic defect is the mutation in the common y-chain (yc) subunit of cytokine receptors. T-cellnumbers are greatly reduced, and although B cells may be normal in number, antibody synthesisis impaired because of the lack of T-cell help. The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiatedepithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.3002. Autosomal recessive is most commonly caused due to deficiency of the enzyme adenosinedeaminase (ADA). The deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and itsderivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especiallythose of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of Tlymphocytes.In the two most common forms (ye mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoidof lymphoid cells. In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall's corpuscles can befound.Note: X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

questions.question: Whichgene is not involved in SCID?
questions.explanation: BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia and not SCID (severe combinedimmunodeficiency).Severe combined immunodeficiency is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immuneresponses. In this condition, the following genes are involved:• JAK3• RAG1• IL-7RPersons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range ofpathogens, including:• Candida albicans• Pneumocystis jiroveci• Pseudomonas•Cytomegalovirus• Varicella

questions.question: A 9-month-old baby was brought with a cough and difficulty in breathing. The baby wasadmitted with similar complaints in the past. On auscultation, coarse crepitations were heard.Quantitative serum immunoglobulin analysis was done and serum IgG, IgA, and IgM levelswere low. His cellular immunity was found to be normal. Which of the following is false abouthis condition?

options.B: Germinal centres of lymph nodes are underdeveloped
options.C: Manifestation is seen usually after 6 months of age

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bruton agammaglobulinemia/ X-linkedagammaglobulinemia (XLA). Even though it is an immunodeficiency disease, it isparadoxically associated with autoimmune diseases such as arthritis and dermatomyositis in 35%of individuals.The classic form of this disease has the following characteristics:•⚫ B cells are absent or markedly decreased and the serum levels of all classes of immunoglobulinsare decreased• T-cell mediated reactions are normal•⚫ Germinal centers of lymph nodes, Peyer's patches, the appendix, and tonsils are underdeveloped301•Plasma cells are absent throughout the bodyXLA is characterized by the failure of B-cell precursors (pro-B cells and pre-B cells) to develop intomature B cells. It is associated with mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Brutontyrosine kinase (Btk).The related gene is located on the long arm of the X chromosome. This X-linked disease is seenalmost entirely in males. The disease usually does not become apparent until about 6 months ofage, when maternal immunoglobulins are depleted.Affected individuals are susceptible to infections with:●• Bacteria that are normally opsonized by antibodies and cleared by phagocytosis•Haemophilus influenzae•Streptococcus pneumonia• Staphylococcus aureus• Giardia lamblia - intestinal protozoan that is normally resisted by secreted IgA, causes persistentinfections• Enteroviruses• Echovirus• Poliovirus•Coxsackievirus

questions.question: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with delayed development. On examination, he hadthe following appearance. Further workup revealed hypocalcemia and an atrial septal defect.Chromosomal studies showed deletion of 22q11. All are true about this syndrome except:290

options.A: It is associated with T cell deficiency
options.B: Thymic aplasia is a prominent feature
options.D: Failure of development of 3rd and 4th pharyngeal arches

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with the image suggests DiGeorge syndrome. It results from the failureof the development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. They give rise to the thymus, theparathyroids, some of the C cells of the thyroid, and the ultimobranchial body.The absence of cell-mediated immunity causes poor defense against certain fungal and viralinfections. The T-cell zones of lymphoid organs, i.e. paracortical areas of the lymph nodes and theperiarteriolar sheaths of the spleen, are depleted. Ig levels may be normal or reduced, dependingon the severity of the T-cell deficiency.

questions.question: Which of the following is least likely to be a feature in a patient with Hyper-IgM syndrome?

options.A: It has X-linked mode of inheritance
options.B: They have normal serum IgG levels
options.C: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia can be seen
options.D: They have normal B-cell and T-cell numbers

questions.explanation: The serum of patients with Hyper-IgM syndrome contains extremely low levels of IgG.In Hyper-IgM syndrome production of IgM antibodies is normal but the ability to produce IgG,IgA, and IgE antibodies is deficient. There are normal or elevated levels of IgM, no IgA or IgE,and extremely low levels of IgG. It affects the ability of helper T cells to deliver activating signalsto B cells and macrophages. However, B cells and T cells counts are normal.It is mostly an X-linked disease, that has mutations in the gene encoding CD40L located on Xq26.If the disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, then there are loss-of-function302mutations involving either CD40 or the enzyme called activation-induced cytidine deaminase(AID).Those with CD40L mutations are also susceptible to pneumonia caused by the intracellularorganism Pneumocystis jiroveci. This is due to CD40L-mediated macrophage activation, a keyreaction of cell-mediated immunity being defective. Recurrent pyogenic infection occurs becausethe level of opsonizing IgG antibodies is low.Occasionally, the IgM antibodies react with blood cells, giving rise to autoimmune hemolyticanemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. In older patients, the proliferation of IgM-producingplasma cells that infiltrate the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract is seen.

questions.question: Patients with isolated Ig A deficiency would have associated deficiency of which of thefollowing IgG subtypes?
questions.explanation: Isolated IgA deficiency is associated with deficiency of IgG subtypes IgG2 and IgG4.IgA deficiency-affected individuals have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA. Itmay be familial or acquired in association with toxoplasmosis, measles, or some other viralinfection.Because IgA is the major antibody in external secretions, mucosal defenses are weakened, andinfections occur in the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urogenital tracts. Symptomatic patientscommonly have recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea.IgA-deficient patients have a high frequency of respiratory tract allergy and a variety ofautoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.question: Which of the following are mutated in X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome?
questions.explanation: The X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome is due to mutations in the gene encoding an adaptormolecule called SLAM-associated protein (SAP).It is characterized by an inability to eliminate Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), eventually leading tofulminant infectious mononucleosis and the development of B-cell tumors.304In about 80% of cases, the disease is due to mutations in the gene encoding the adaptor moleculeSAP. Defects in SAP contribute to attenuated NK cell and T-cell activation, resulting in increasedsusceptibility to viral infections.Option B: LYST gene is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome.Option C: BTK gene is associated with Isolated growth hormone deficiency type III.Option D: TBX1 gene is associated with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome.

questions.question: Which of the following lymphoid tissue findings is seen most commonly in patients withcommon variable hypogammaglobulinemia?
questions.explanation: Normal B-cell count is most commonly seen in lymphoid tissues of individuals with the commonvariable hypogammaglobulinemia.It is a heterogeneous group of disorders in which the common feature ishypogammaglobulinemia, generally affecting all the antibody classes, but sometimes only IgG.In contrast to X-linked agammaglobulinemia, most individuals with common variableimmunodeficiency have normal or near-normal numbers of B-cells in the blood and lymphoidtissues. These B cells, however, are not able to differentiate into plasma cells.FDA approved XEMBIFY in 2019, 20% immunoglobulin solution for subcutaneous injection. It isindicated for the use of primary humoral immunodeficiency disorders in patients 2years of ageand older.

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of red rashes over his skin. His mother says thatthe child will be constantly scratching the rashes. On asking any previous history she says thechild keeps getting recurrent infections which mostly require hospitalization. Bloodinvestigations showed a low platelet count. Which of the following is false regarding thissyndrome?
questions.explanation: The given history with eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia points towardsWiskott-Aldrich syndrome. In this condition, IgM levels in the serum are low.Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the Wiskott-Aldrichsyndrome protein (WASP), which is located on Xp11.23. The X-linked disease is characterized bythrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in earlydeath.Platelets are small in size. The thymus is morphologically normal, at least early in the course ofthe disease, but there is the progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and in theT-cell zones (paracortical areas) of the lymph nodes, with variable defects in cellular immunity.Patients do not make antibodies to polysaccharide antigens, and the response to protein antigensis poor. IgM levels are low, IgG is usually normal, while the levels of IgA and IgE are oftenelevated. Patients are prone to developing B-cell lymphomas.

questions.question: A 5-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaints of repeated falls while walking forthe past 1 year. She had difficulty in eating, gripping, or holding things. On examination,hand mouth incoordination and slurring of speech were noted. On ocular examination, thefollowing finding was seen. All are true about this condition except:293

options.A: There is defective production of IgA and IgG2
options.B: Affected gene is located on chromosome 11
options.D: There is increased risk of malignancy

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario and image showing telangiectasia are diagnostic ofataxia-telangiectasia. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder, not autosomal dominant.305The most prominent humoral immune abnormalities are defective production of IgA and IgG2.The gene responsible for this disorder is located on chromosome 11 and encodes a protein calledATM. The ATM protein is a sensor of DNA damage (double-strand breaks), and it activates p53 byphosphorylation.Ataxia-telangiectasia is characterized by abnormal gait (ataxia), vascular malformations(telangiectases), neurologic deficits, increased incidence of tumors, and immunodeficiency. It mayaffect both B and T cells.There is a high incidence of lymphomas and leukemias.

Target cells of HIV include CD4+ helper T cells(worst affected), monocyte-macrophages, and dendritic cells.•The virus core contains:Major capsid protein p24• Nucleocapsid protein p7/p9• Two copies of viral genomic RNA•The three viral enzymes (protease, reverse transcriptase, and integrase)The viral core is surrounded by a matrix protein called p17, which lies underneath the virionenvelope. The viral envelope is studded by two viral glycoproteins, gp120 and gp41, which arecritical for HIV infection of cells.Viral glycoprotein gp120 binds to CD4+ cells in the host. questions.question: Which is the most common CNS neoplasm in HIV patients?
questions.explanation: The most common central nervous system (CNS) neoplasm in patients with HIV infection isprimary CNS lymphoma.Lymphomas are the most common CNS neoplasm in immunosuppressed individuals, includingthose with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and immunosuppression aftertransplantation. They are associated with latent infection with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The vastmajority of primary brain lymphomas are of B-cell origin.At least two mechanisms appear to underlie the increased risk of B-cell tumors in HIV-infectedindividuals. They are:• The unchecked proliferation of B cells infected with oncogenic herpes viruses in the setting ofprofound T-cell depletion (AIDS).•Germinal center B-cell hyperplasia in the setting of early HIV infection.The most common site for lymphoma in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome(AIDS) is the central nervous system (CNS).

questions.question: A 25-year-old man, who is HIV-positive, presents with generalized lymphadenopathy. Whichof the histopathological features is least likely to be seen on lymph node biopsy?

options.D: Collection of monocytoid B Cells in sinuses

questions.explanation: Hematoxylin bodies are seen in lymph nodes in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).Features of AIDS-related lymphadenopathy:Early stages of HIV infection:• Florid hyperplasia of B cell follicles• Follicle lysis•Monocytoid B cells in sinuses• Neutrophils and dermatopathic lymphadenopathy⚫The interfollicular zone shows vascular proliferation, which may progress to Kaposi sarcomaLate stages of HIV infection:•Severe lymphoid involution●Possible hyalinization of the germinal centers• Burnt-out lymph nodes, which become atrophic and may harbor numerous opportunisticpathogens, often within macrophages

questions.question: A 50-year-old HIV-seropositive man presents with raised violaceous plaques over the legs.Microscopy shows a lesion in the dermis with dilated, jagged vascular channels lined andsurrounded by plump spindle cells. It contains red cells with marked hemorrhage,hemosiderin pigment, and mononuclear inflammation. Mitotic figures are also seen. Whichorganism is associated with this tumor?
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8).Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm, that is highly associated with acquired immunodeficiencysyndrome (AIDS). It is the most common cancer seen in patients having AIDS. Though the308incidence of Kaposi carcinoma reduced, it still occurs in 2-3% of HIV-infected individuals.The pathogenesis of Kaposi sarcoma that is caused by HHV8 includes:• A virally encoded G protein that induces VEGF production, stimulating endothelial growth•The lytic infection caused by HHV8 increases the pro-inflammatory cytokines• HHV8 encoded proteins inhibit the p53 induced apoptosisThe given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologicappearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:Kaposi sarcomaProliferatingspindle cells

questions.question: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient has patchy pneumonia. Smears of induced sputum andsedimented cells from lavage fluid stained with methenamine silver are as seen below. Whichis the most likely organism implicated?295
questions.explanation: The smears stained with methenamine silver show black-colored stained cysts resemblingthe crushed ping pong balls of Pneumocystis jirovecii.309Approximately 15% to 30% of untreated HIV-infected people develop pneumonia during thecourse of the disease. It is mainly caused by the fungus P. jirovecii (reactivation of prior latentinfection).Pneumocystis jirovecii310
